Background.value: The Paracel Islands are surrounded by productive fishing grounds and by potential oil and gas reserves. In 1932, French Indochina annexed the islands and set up a weather station on Pattle Island; maintenance was continued by its successor, Vietnam. China has occupied all the Paracel Islands since 1974, when its troops seized a South Vietnamese garrison occupying the western islands. China built a military installation on Woody Island with an airfield and artificial harbor. The islands also are claimed by Taiwan and Vietnam.

Elevation extremes.highest point: unnamed location on Rocky Island 14 m

Location.value: Southeastern Asia, group of small islands and reefs in the South China Sea, about one-third of the way from central Vietnam to the northern Philippines

Geography - note.value: composed of 130 small coral islands and reefs divided into the northeast Amphitrite Group and the western Crescent Group

Land use.value: arable land 0%; permanent crops 0%; permanent pasture 0%

Economy - overview.value: The islands have the potential for oil and gas development. Waters around the islands support commercial fishing, but the islands themselves are not populated on a permanent basis.

Ports and terminals.value: small Chinese port facilities on Woody Island and Duncan Island

Disputes - international.value: occupied by China, also claimed by Taiwan and Vietnam
